	<item>
				<title>Young Woman And Client In Flowers Shop</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?attachment_id=65</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 14:05:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/wp-content/uploads/sites/17/2014/07/bigstock-Young-Woman-And-Client-In-Flow-23747432.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Female sales assistant working as florist and holding bouquet with customer in background. Horizontal shape waist up]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>65</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-23 14:05:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 14:05:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>young-woman-and-client-in-flowers-shop</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/forums/forum/product-support/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 Jul 2014 12:31:19 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Forums for individual product support topics]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:6:{s:5:"width";i:202;s:6:"height";i:55;s:4:"file";s:17:"2014/07/logo2.png";s:5:"sizes";a:3:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:5:{s:4:"file";s:16:"logo2-150x55.png";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:55;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";s:20:"ewww_image_optimizer";s:52:"Reduced by 29.4% (824&nbsp;B) - Previously Optimized";}s:11:"ht-kb-thumb";a:5:{s:4:"file";s:15:"logo2-50x13.png";s:5:"width";i:50;s:6:"height";i:13;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";s:20:"ewww_image_optimizer";s:33:"No savings - Previously Optimized";}s:14:"post-thumbnail";a:5:{s:4:"file";s:15:"logo2-60x55.png";s:5:"width";i:60;s:6:"height";i:55;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";s:20:"ewww_image_optimizer";s:50:"Reduced by 7.4% (98&nbsp;B) - Previously Optimized";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}s:20:"ewww_image_optimizer";s:29:"Reduced by 11.1% (412&nbsp;B)";}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>logo</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?attachment_id=177</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Jul 2014 18:37:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/wp-content/uploads/sites/17/2014/07/logo1.png</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>177</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-29 18:37:32</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-29 18:37:32</wp:post_date_gmt>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Can I Change My Username?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/can-i-change-my-username/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Jul 2014 17:26:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=23</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How Secure Is My Password?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-secure-is-my-password/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:25:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=24</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Where Can I Upload My Avatar?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/where-can-i-upload-my-avatar/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=25</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How Do I Change My Timezone?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-change-my-timezone/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=26</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How Do I Change My Password?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-change-my-password/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=27</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How Do I Close My Account?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-close-my-account/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=28</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1406463139.8498198986053466796875;s:7:"message";s:46:"richard changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:7:"richard";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>36</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Brittani Tess]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>demo3@herothemes.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>192.168.0.1</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2014-07-27 18:14:38</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2014-07-27 18:14:38</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[HelpGuru - A fantastic Knowledge Base theme with in-built knowledge base engine and rating system.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>8472</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_result</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1406484878.8986299037933349609375;s:7:"message";s:28:"Akismet cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:5:"demo3";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>What Technologies Are Used?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/what-technologies-are-used/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=29</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>29</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>What Are The API Limits?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/what-are-the-api-limits/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:26:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=30</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Why Was My Developer Application Rejected?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/why-was-my-developer-application-rejected/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:28:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=31</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. 		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How Do I Get An API Key?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-get-an-api-key/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:28:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=32</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Installation Guide</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/installation-guide/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:28:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=33</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Creating Articles</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/creating-articles/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:28:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=34</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2014-07-27 18:15:15</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Vestibulum erat augue, convallis non gravida vel, pulvinar quis quam. Sed elementum mauris vel massa vestibulum, sed fringilla justo fermentum. Duis fermentum dictum eros, eget placerat risus consequat ac. Aenean in eleifend urna, sed dapibus tortor. Proin interdum sed lectus vitae lobortis. Sed blandit accumsan facilisis. Integer tempus malesuada neque eget pretium. Fusce non tortor ut nibh rutrum dictum. Vestibulum et fermentum justo.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>8472</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_result</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1406484915.251202106475830078125;s:7:"message";s:28:"Akismet cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:5:"demo3";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How To Update Seamlessly Every Time</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-to-update-seamlessly-every-time/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:28:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=35</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>_bbp_forum_subforum_count</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_bbp_reply_count</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
				<title>Where are your offices located?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/where-are-your-offices-located/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 09:58:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[demo3]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=123</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #555555">In WordPress, you can write either posts or Pages. When you’re writing a regular blog entry, you write a post. Posts, in a default setup, appear in reverse chronological order on your blog’s home page.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">Pages are for content such as “About,” “Contact,” etc. Pages live outside of the normal blog chronology, and are often used to present timeless information about yourself or your site — information that is always applicable. You can use Pages to organize and manage any content.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">General</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">In general, Pages are very similar to Posts in that they both have Titles and Content and can use your WordPress Theme templates files to maintain a consistent look throughout your site. Pages, though, have several key distinctions that make them quite different from Posts.</p>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages Are:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are for content that is less time-dependent than Posts.</li>
	<li>Pages can be organized into pages and <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Organizing_Your_Pages">subpages</a>.</li>
	<li>Pages can use different <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Page_Templates">Page Templates</a> which can include <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Template Files</a>,<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tags</a> and other PHP code.</li>
</ul>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages are Not:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are not Posts, nor are they excerpted from larger works of fiction. They do not cycle through your blog’s main page. WordPress Plugins are available to change the defaults if necessary.</li>
	<li>Pages cannot be associated with Categories and cannot be assigned Tags. The organizational structure for Pages comes only from their hierarchical interrelationships, and not from Tags or Categories.</li>
	<li>Pages are not files. They are stored in your database just like Posts are.</li>
	<li>Pages are not included in your site’s feed.</li>
</ul>
<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Changing the URL of Your Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">To change the URL part (also referred to as “slug”) containing the name of your Page, use the “Edit” (or “Change Permalinks” in older WordPress versions) button under the Page title on the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Writing Posts" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Writing_Posts">Edit screen</a> of the particular Page, accessible from <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Pages">Pages</a> tab of WordPress<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration Panel</a>.</p>

<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Creating a List of Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">WordPress is able to <i>automatically</i> generate a list of Pages on your site within the sidebar or footer, for example, using a <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tag</a> called <tt>wp_list_pages()</tt>. See the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags/wp list pages" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_pages">wp_list_pages</a>page for information on how to customize how WordPress displays the list of Pages on your site.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">There are also WordPress Plugins that will help you display a list of Pages within in Posts and in other areas of your WordPress Theme.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">Creating Your Own Page Templates</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">The files defining each Page Template are found in your <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Themes</a> directory under <tt>/wp-content</tt>. To create a new Custom Page Template for a Page you must create a file using a plain text editor (e.g Notepad or TextWrangler). Let’s call our first Page Template<tt>snarfer.php</tt>.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">At the top of the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file, put the following:</p>

<pre style="color: #555555">&lt;?php
/*
Template Name: Snarfer
*/
?&gt;</pre>
<p style="color: #555555">The above code is required and defines the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file as the “Snarfer” Template. “Snarfer” may be replaced with most any text to change the name of the Page Template. The Template Name will appear in the WordPress Theme Editor for editing. For more information on Theme naming conventions see <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Template_Files_List">reserved Theme filenames</a> for file names you should <i>not</i> use.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Our content policy</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/our-content-policy/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:13:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=124</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #555555">In WordPress, you can write either posts or Pages. When you’re writing a regular blog entry, you write a post. Posts, in a default setup, appear in reverse chronological order on your blog’s home page.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">Pages are for content such as “About,” “Contact,” etc. Pages live outside of the normal blog chronology, and are often used to present timeless information about yourself or your site — information that is always applicable. You can use Pages to organize and manage any content.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">General</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">In general, Pages are very similar to Posts in that they both have Titles and Content and can use your WordPress Theme templates files to maintain a consistent look throughout your site. Pages, though, have several key distinctions that make them quite different from Posts.</p>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages Are:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are for content that is less time-dependent than Posts.</li>
	<li>Pages can be organized into pages and <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Organizing_Your_Pages">subpages</a>.</li>
	<li>Pages can use different <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Page_Templates">Page Templates</a> which can include <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Template Files</a>,<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tags</a> and other PHP code.</li>
</ul>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages are Not:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are not Posts, nor are they excerpted from larger works of fiction. They do not cycle through your blog’s main page. WordPress Plugins are available to change the defaults if necessary.</li>
	<li>Pages cannot be associated with Categories and cannot be assigned Tags. The organizational structure for Pages comes only from their hierarchical interrelationships, and not from Tags or Categories.</li>
	<li>Pages are not files. They are stored in your database just like Posts are.</li>
	<li>Pages are not included in your site’s feed.</li>
</ul>
<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Changing the URL of Your Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">To change the URL part (also referred to as “slug”) containing the name of your Page, use the “Edit” (or “Change Permalinks” in older WordPress versions) button under the Page title on the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Writing Posts" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Writing_Posts">Edit screen</a> of the particular Page, accessible from <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Pages">Pages</a> tab of WordPress<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration Panel</a>.</p>

<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Creating a List of Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">WordPress is able to <i>automatically</i> generate a list of Pages on your site within the sidebar or footer, for example, using a <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tag</a> called <tt>wp_list_pages()</tt>. See the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags/wp list pages" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_pages">wp_list_pages</a>page for information on how to customize how WordPress displays the list of Pages on your site.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">There are also WordPress Plugins that will help you display a list of Pages within in Posts and in other areas of your WordPress Theme.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">Creating Your Own Page Templates</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">The files defining each Page Template are found in your <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Themes</a> directory under <tt>/wp-content</tt>. To create a new Custom Page Template for a Page you must create a file using a plain text editor (e.g Notepad or TextWrangler). Let’s call our first Page Template<tt>snarfer.php</tt>.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">At the top of the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file, put the following:</p>

<pre style="color: #555555">&lt;?php
/*
Template Name: Snarfer
*/
?&gt;</pre>
<p style="color: #555555">The above code is required and defines the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file as the “Snarfer” Template. “Snarfer” may be replaced with most any text to change the name of the Page Template. The Template Name will appear in the WordPress Theme Editor for editing. For more information on Theme naming conventions see <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Template_Files_List">reserved Theme filenames</a> for file names you should <i>not</i> use.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>124</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-27 10:13:51</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-27 10:13:51</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>our-content-policy</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>ht_kb</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="ht_kb_tag" nicename="content"><![CDATA[content]]></category>
		<category domain="ht_kb_tag" nicename="content-policy"><![CDATA[content policy]]></category>
		<category domain="ht_kb_category" nicename="copyright-legal"><![CDATA[Copyright &amp; Legal]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How do I contact legal?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-contact-legal/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:15:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=126</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #555555">In WordPress, you can write either posts or Pages. When you’re writing a regular blog entry, you write a post. Posts, in a default setup, appear in reverse chronological order on your blog’s home page.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">Pages are for content such as “About,” “Contact,” etc. Pages live outside of the normal blog chronology, and are often used to present timeless information about yourself or your site — information that is always applicable. You can use Pages to organize and manage any content.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">General</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">In general, Pages are very similar to Posts in that they both have Titles and Content and can use your WordPress Theme templates files to maintain a consistent look throughout your site. Pages, though, have several key distinctions that make them quite different from Posts.</p>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages Are:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are for content that is less time-dependent than Posts.</li>
	<li>Pages can be organized into pages and <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Organizing_Your_Pages">subpages</a>.</li>
	<li>Pages can use different <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Page_Templates">Page Templates</a> which can include <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Template Files</a>,<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tags</a> and other PHP code.</li>
</ul>
<p style="color: #555555"><b>What Pages are Not:</b></p>

<ul style="color: #555555">
	<li>Pages are not Posts, nor are they excerpted from larger works of fiction. They do not cycle through your blog’s main page. WordPress Plugins are available to change the defaults if necessary.</li>
	<li>Pages cannot be associated with Categories and cannot be assigned Tags. The organizational structure for Pages comes only from their hierarchical interrelationships, and not from Tags or Categories.</li>
	<li>Pages are not files. They are stored in your database just like Posts are.</li>
	<li>Pages are not included in your site’s feed.</li>
</ul>
<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Changing the URL of Your Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">To change the URL part (also referred to as “slug”) containing the name of your Page, use the “Edit” (or “Change Permalinks” in older WordPress versions) button under the Page title on the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Writing Posts" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Writing_Posts">Edit screen</a> of the particular Page, accessible from <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Pages">Pages</a> tab of WordPress<a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration Panel</a>.</p>

<h3 style="font-weight: 600;color: #363d40">Creating a List of Pages</h3>
<p style="color: #555555">WordPress is able to <i>automatically</i> generate a list of Pages on your site within the sidebar or footer, for example, using a <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tag</a> called <tt>wp_list_pages()</tt>. See the <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Template Tags/wp list pages" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_pages">wp_list_pages</a>page for information on how to customize how WordPress displays the list of Pages on your site.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">There are also WordPress Plugins that will help you display a list of Pages within in Posts and in other areas of your WordPress Theme.</p>

<h2 style="font-weight: bold;color: #363d40">Creating Your Own Page Templates</h2>
<p style="color: #555555">The files defining each Page Template are found in your <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Themes</a> directory under <tt>/wp-content</tt>. To create a new Custom Page Template for a Page you must create a file using a plain text editor (e.g Notepad or TextWrangler). Let’s call our first Page Template<tt>snarfer.php</tt>.</p>
<p style="color: #555555">At the top of the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file, put the following:</p>

<pre style="color: #555555">&lt;?php
/*
Template Name: Snarfer
*/
?&gt;</pre>
<p style="color: #555555">The above code is required and defines the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file as the “Snarfer” Template. “Snarfer” may be replaced with most any text to change the name of the Page Template. The Template Name will appear in the WordPress Theme Editor for editing. For more information on Theme naming conventions see <a style="color: #e36f3c" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Template_Files_List">reserved Theme filenames</a> for file names you should <i>not</i> use.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:10:"HT_Vote_Up":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:10;s:2:"ip";s:13:"188.23.199.66";s:4:"time";i:1407303205;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
