	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How do I file a DMCA?</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/how-do-i-file-a-dmca/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:18:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[demo1]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=127</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In WordPress, you can write either posts or Pages. When you’re writing a regular blog entry, you write a post. Posts, in a default setup, appear in reverse chronological order on your blog’s home page.

Pages are for content such as “About,” “Contact,” etc. Pages live outside of the normal blog chronology, and are often used to present timeless information about yourself or your site — information that is always applicable. You can use Pages to organize and manage any content.
<h2>General</h2>
In general, Pages are very similar to Posts in that they both have Titles and Content and can use your WordPress Theme templates files to maintain a consistent look throughout your site. Pages, though, have several key distinctions that make them quite different from Posts.

<b>What Pages Are:</b>
<ul>
	<li>Pages are for content that is less time-dependent than Posts.</li>
	<li>Pages can be organized into pages and <a title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Organizing_Your_Pages">subpages</a>.</li>
	<li>Pages can use different <a title="" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Pages#Page_Templates">Page Templates</a> which can include <a title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Template Files</a>,<a title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tags</a> and other PHP code.</li>
</ul>
<b>What Pages are Not:</b>
<ul>
	<li>Pages are not Posts, nor are they excerpted from larger works of fiction. They do not cycle through your blog’s main page. WordPress Plugins are available to change the defaults if necessary.</li>
	<li>Pages cannot be associated with Categories and cannot be assigned Tags. The organizational structure for Pages comes only from their hierarchical interrelationships, and not from Tags or Categories.</li>
	<li>Pages are not files. They are stored in your database just like Posts are.</li>
	<li>Pages are not included in your site’s feed.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Changing the URL of Your Pages</h3>
To change the URL part (also referred to as “slug”) containing the name of your Page, use the “Edit” (or “Change Permalinks” in older WordPress versions) button under the Page title on the <a title="Writing Posts" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Writing_Posts">Edit screen</a> of the particular Page, accessible from <a title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Pages">Pages</a> tab of WordPress<a title="Administration Panels" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration Panel</a>.
<h3>Creating a List of Pages</h3>
WordPress is able to <i>automatically</i> generate a list of Pages on your site within the sidebar or footer, for example, using a <a title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">Template Tag</a> called <tt>wp_list_pages()</tt>. See the <a title="Template Tags/wp list pages" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_pages">wp_list_pages</a>page for information on how to customize how WordPress displays the list of Pages on your site.

There are also WordPress Plugins that will help you display a list of Pages within in Posts and in other areas of your WordPress Theme.
<h2>Creating Your Own Page Templates</h2>
The files defining each Page Template are found in your <a title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Themes</a> directory under <tt>/wp-content</tt>. To create a new Custom Page Template for a Page you must create a file using a plain text editor (e.g Notepad or TextWrangler). Let’s call our first Page Template<tt>snarfer.php</tt>.

At the top of the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file, put the following:

[php]&lt;?php
/*
Template Name: Snarfer
*/
?&gt;
[/php]

The above code is required and defines the <tt>snarfer.php</tt> file as the “Snarfer” Template. “Snarfer” may be replaced with most any text to change the name of the Page Template. The Template Name will appear in the WordPress Theme Editor for editing. For more information on Theme naming conventions see <a title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Template_Files_List">reserved Theme filenames</a> for file names you should <i>not</i> use.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>WordPress and CSS</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/wordpress-and-css/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:27:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=128</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;">WordPress relies heavily on the presentation styles within CSS. With the use of <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Themes</a>, you have an almost infinite choice of layout options. WordPress Themes make it easy to change your website look, and open up the field to help you <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development">create your own Theme</a> and page layout.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Glossary" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Glossary#CSS">CSS</a> stands for <b>Cascading Style Sheets</b>. It allows you to store style presentation information (like colors and layout) separate from your HTML structure. This allows precision control of your website layout and makes your pages faster and easier to update.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">This article briefly describes the use of CSS in WordPress, and lists some references for further information. For information on CSS itself, see <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Know Your Sources" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Know_Your_Sources#CSS">Know Your Sources#CSS</a>.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline">WordPress and CSS</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000;">WordPress Themes use a combination of <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Templates">template files</a>, <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags">template tags</a>, and CSS files to generate your WordPress site's look.</p>

<dl style="color: #000000;"><dt style="font-weight: bold;">Template Files </dt><dd><a class="mw-redirect" style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Template files</a> are the building blocks which come together to create your site. In the<a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Site Architecture 1.5" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Site_Architecture_1.5">WordPress Theme structure</a>, the header, sidebar, content, and footer are all contained within individual files. They join together to create your page. This allows you to customize the building blocks. For example, in the default WordPress Theme, the multi-post view found on the front page, category, <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Creating an Archive Index" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Creating_an_Archive_Index">archives</a>, and <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Creating a Search Page" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Creating_a_Search_Page">search</a> web pages on your site, the sidebar is present. Click on any post, you will be taken to the single post view and the sidebar will now be gone. You can <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="The Loop in Action" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/The_Loop_in_Action">choose which parts and pieces appear</a> on your page, and customize them individually, allowing for a different header or sidebar to appear on all pages within a specific category. And more. For a more extensive introduction to Templates, see <a class="mw-redirect" style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Stepping Into Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Templates">Stepping Into Templates</a>.</dd><dt style="font-weight: bold;">Template Tags </dt><dd>Template tags are the bits of code which provide instructions and requests for information stored within the WordPress database. Some of these are highly configurable, allowing you to customize the date, time, lists, and other elements displayed on your website. You can learn more about template tags in <a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Stepping Into Template Tags" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Stepping_Into_Template_Tags">Stepping Into Template Tags</a>.</dd><dt style="font-weight: bold;">Stylesheet </dt><dd>The CSS file is where it all comes together. On every template file within your site there are HTML elements wrapped around your template tags and content. In the stylesheet within each Theme are rules to control the design and layout of each HTML element. Without these instructions, your page would simply look like a long typed page. With these instructions, you can move the building block structures around, making your header very long and filled with graphics or photographs, or simple and narrow. Your site can "float" in the middle of the viewer's screen with space on the left and right, or stretch across the screen, filling the whole page. Your sidebar can be on the right or left, or even start midway down the page. How you style your page is up to you. But the instructions for styling are found in the <tt>style.css</tt> file within each Theme folder.</dd></dl><a id="WordPress_Generated_Classes" style="color: #21759b;" name="WordPress_Generated_Classes"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">WordPress Generated Classes</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000;">Several classes for aligning images and block elements (<tt>div</tt>, <tt>p</tt>, <tt>table</tt> etc.) were introduced in WordPress 2.5: <tt>aligncenter</tt>,<tt>alignleft</tt> and <tt>alignright</tt>. In addition the class <tt>alignnone</tt> is added to images that are not aligned, so they can be styled differently if needed.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The same classes are used to align images that have a caption (as of WordPress 2.6). Three additional CSS classes are needed for the captions, together the alignment and caption classes are:</p>

[css]
/* =WordPress Core
-------------------------------------------------------------- */
.alignnone {
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

.aligncenter,
div.aligncenter {
    display: block;
    margin: 5px auto 5px auto;
}

.alignright {
    float:right;
    margin: 5px 0 20px 20px;
}

.alignleft {
    float: left;
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

.aligncenter {
    display: block;
    margin: 5px auto 5px auto;
}

a img.alignright {
    float: right;
    margin: 5px 0 20px 20px;
}

a img.alignnone {
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

a img.alignleft {
    float: left;
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

a img.aligncenter {
    display: block;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto
}

.wp-caption {
    background: #fff;
    border: 1px solid #f0f0f0;
    max-width: 96%; /* Image does not overflow the content area */
    padding: 5px 3px 10px;
    text-align: center;
}

.wp-caption.alignnone {
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

.wp-caption.alignleft {
    margin: 5px 20px 20px 0;
}

.wp-caption.alignright {
    margin: 5px 0 20px 20px;
}

.wp-caption img {
    border: 0 none;
    height: auto;
    margin: 0;
    max-width: 98.5%;
    padding: 0;
    width: auto;
}

.wp-caption p.wp-caption-text {
    font-size: 11px;
    line-height: 17px;
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0 4px 5px;
}
[/css]

<p style="color: #000000;">Each Theme should have these or similar styles in its <tt>style.css</tt> file to be able to display images and captions properly. The exact HTML elements and class and ID values will depend on the structure of the Theme you are using.</p>
<a id="Templates_and_CSS" style="color: #21759b;" name="Templates_and_CSS"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Templates and CSS</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000;">To help you understand more about how CSS works in relationship to your web page, you may wish to read some of the articles cited in these lists:</p>

<ul style="color: #000000;">
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Using Themes" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Using Themes</a> - There are also many advanced articles in this list.</li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Templates" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Templates">Templates</a> - Comprehensive list of WordPress Theme and Template articles.</li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development">Theme Development</a> - WordPress Theme Development guide and code standards.</li>
</ul>
<a id="WordPress_Layout_Help" style="color: #21759b;" name="WordPress_Layout_Help"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">WordPress Layout Help</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000;">If you are having some problems or questions about your WordPress Theme or layout, begin by checking the website of the Theme author to see if there is an upgrade or whether there are answers to your questions. Here are some other resources:</p>

<ul style="color: #000000;">
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="WordPress Lessons" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Lessons#Designing_Your_WordPress_Site">Lessons on Designing Your WordPress Site</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Site Design and Layout" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Site_Design_and_Layout">Site Design and Layout</a> - Comprehensive list of resources related to site design in WordPress.</li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="FAQ Layout and Design" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/FAQ_Layout_and_Design">FAQ Layout and Design</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="CSS_Resources" style="color: #21759b;" name="CSS_Resources"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">CSS Resources</span></h2>
<ul style="color: #000000;">
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Finding Your CSS Styles" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Finding_Your_CSS_Styles">Finding Your CSS Styles</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="CSS Troubleshooting" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/CSS_Troubleshooting">CSS Troubleshooting</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="CSS Fixing Browser Bugs" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/CSS_Fixing_Browser_Bugs">CSS Fixing Browser Bugs</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="CSS Coding Standards" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/CSS_Coding_Standards">CSS Coding Standards</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="CSS Shorthand" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/CSS_Shorthand">CSS Shorthand</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Know Your Sources" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Know_Your_Sources#CSS">Know Your Sources#CSS</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Conditional Comment CSS" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Conditional_Comment_CSS">Conditional Comment CSS</a></li>
	<li><a style="color: #4ca6cf;" title="Validating a Website" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Validating_a_Website">Validating a Website</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Know your sources</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/know-your-sources/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:29:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=129</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2 class="pagetitle" style="font-weight: bold;color: #666666">For Your Records</h2>
<p style="color: #000000">As you design your Theme or style, you will be using HTML and CSS references. Here are a few resources you will become very familiar with over time. We recommend that you save or bookmark this page as a reference while you're working on your <a style="color: #4ca6cf" title="Theme Development" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development">WordPress Themes</a>.</p>
<a id="HTML" style="color: #21759b" name="HTML"></a>
<h1><span class="mw-headline">HTML</span></h1>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/learn" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/learn">Learn How to Make Websites</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/" href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/">XHTML-1 Reference</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/" href="http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/">HTML Markup Reference</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/" href="http://www.w3.org/">World Wide Web Consortium</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.htmldog.com/" href="http://www.htmldog.com/">HTML Dog</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="PHP" style="color: #21759b" name="PHP"></a>
<h1><span class="mw-headline">PHP</span></h1>
<ul style="color: #000000">

	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://php.resourceindex.com/" href="http://php.resourceindex.com/">PHP Resource Index</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Learning_PHP" style="color: #21759b" name="Learning_PHP"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Learning PHP</span></h2>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://adambrown.info/b/widgets/easy-php-tutorial-for-wordpress-users/" href="http://adambrown.info/b/widgets/easy-php-tutorial-for-wordpress-users/">Very Basic PHP Tutorial for WordPress Users</a></li>

<a id="CSS" style="color: #21759b" name="CSS"></a>
<h1><span class="mw-headline">CSS</span></h1>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/2002/03/new-to-w3c" href="http://www.w3.org/2002/03/new-to-w3c">Finding Your Way at W3C</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS1" href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS1">CSS-1 Reference</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/Style/css1-updates/REC-CSS1-19990111-errata.html" href="http://www.w3.org/Style/css1-updates/REC-CSS1-19990111-errata.html">Updates to CSS-1</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/" href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/">CSS-2 Reference</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3.org/Style/css2-updates/REC-CSS2-19980512-errata.html" href="http://www.w3.org/Style/css2-updates/REC-CSS2-19980512-errata.html">Updates to CSS-2</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://gallery.theopalgroup.com/selectoracle/" href="http://gallery.theopalgroup.com/selectoracle/">Selectoracle - Enter CSS Style Sheet and All is Explained</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.websitetips.com/css/index.shtml" href="http://www.websitetips.com/css/index.shtml">Websitetips.com - CSS Section of Resources and Links</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Learning_CSS" style="color: #21759b" name="Learning_CSS"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Learning CSS</span></h2>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS">MDN</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3schools.com/" href="http://www.w3schools.com/">W3 Schools</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.htmldog.com/guides/cssbeginner/" href="http://www.htmldog.com/guides/cssbeginner/">HTML Dog CSS Beginners Guide</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.mako4css.com/" href="http://www.mako4css.com/">The CSSShark Answers FAQs</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.yourhtmlsource.com/stylesheets/introduction.html" href="http://www.yourhtmlsource.com/stylesheets/introduction.html">HTML Source's Introduction to CSS Stylesheets</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.wpdfd.com/editorial/basics/index.html" href="http://www.wpdfd.com/editorial/basics/index.html">Web Page Design for Designers - CSS From the Ground Up</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.westciv.com/style_master/academy/hands_on_tutorial/" href="http://www.westciv.com/style_master/academy/hands_on_tutorial/">Westciv's CSS Hands on Tutorial</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.alvit.de/handbook/" href="http://www.alvit.de/handbook/">The Web Developer's Network</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.mezzoblue.com/css/cribsheet/" href="http://www.mezzoblue.com/css/cribsheet/">Mezzoblue's CSS Cribsheet</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://pineapple.io/resources/tagged/css?type=tutorials&amp;sort=all_time" href="http://pineapple.io/resources/tagged/css?type=tutorials&amp;sort=all_time">Pineapple CSS Tutorials</a></li>
</ul>

</ul>
<a id="CSS_Expertise_and_Examples" style="color: #21759b" name="CSS_Expertise_and_Examples"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">CSS Expertise and Examples</span></h2>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.meyerweb.com/eric/css/" href="http://www.meyerweb.com/eric/css/">Eric Meyer's CSS Edge</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.ericmeyeroncss.com/" href="http://www.ericmeyeroncss.com/">Eric Meyer on CSS (site based on book)</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.csszengarden.com/" href="http://www.csszengarden.com/">CSS Zen Garden - the art of the possible in CSS</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.alistapart.com/" href="http://www.alistapart.com/">A List Apart</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.oswd.co" href="http://www.oswd.co/">Open Source Web Design</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Layout_Resources" style="color: #21759b" name="Layout_Resources"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Layout Resources</span></h2>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.positioniseverything.net" href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/">Position Is Everything</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.positioniseverything.net/guests/3colcomplex.html" href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/guests/3colcomplex.html">Position is Everything's Complex 3 Column - Perched on a Lily Pad</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.positioniseverything.net/piefecta-rigid.html" href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/piefecta-rigid.html">Position is Everything Piefecta Ridid 3-Column Layout</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/flexiblelayouts/" href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/flexiblelayouts/">A List Apart's Flexible Layouts with CSS Positioning</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://glish.com/css/" href="http://glish.com/css/">Glish.com CSS Layout Techniques</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/negativemargins/" href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/negativemargins/">Creating Liquid Layouts with Negative Margins</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/fauxcolumns/" href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/fauxcolumns/">Faux Columns: Column Stretches</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://imaginaryworld.net/layouts/" href="http://imaginaryworld.net/layouts/">Imaginary World's Internet Brain CSS Layout Templates</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.brainjar.com/css/positioning/default.asp" href="http://www.brainjar.com/css/positioning/default.asp">Brainjar's CSS Positioning</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_examples.asp" href="http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_examples.asp">CSS Examples from W3 Schools</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.stopdesign.com/articles/absolute/" href="http://www.stopdesign.com/articles/absolute/">Stopdesign's Making the Absolute Relative</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.mako4css.com/Tutorial.htm" href="http://www.mako4css.com/Tutorial.htm">Mako's CSS Positioning</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.mardiros.net/liquid-css-layouts.html" href="http://www.mardiros.net/liquid-css-layouts.html">Liquid CSS Layouts - Design Alternative to Table Based Websites</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.bluerobot.com/web/layouts/" href="http://www.bluerobot.com/web/layouts/">The Layout Reservoir</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://css.maxdesign.com.au/" href="http://css.maxdesign.com.au/">MaxDesign's CSS Layout Examples and Guides</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.meyerweb.com/eric/css/" href="http://www.meyerweb.com/eric/css/">Eric Meyer's Articles on CSS</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.yourhtmlsource.com/stylesheets/csslayout.html" href="http://www.yourhtmlsource.com/stylesheets/csslayout.html">CSS Layout Tutorial</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://webhost.bridgew.edu/etribou/layouts/" href="http://webhost.bridgew.edu/etribou/layouts/">RuthsarianLayouts's CSS Layout Templates and Tips</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://css-discuss.incutio.com/?page=CssLayouts" href="http://css-discuss.incutio.com/?page=CssLayouts">CSSLayouts Tips and Techniques</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Boxes_and_Design_Elements" style="color: #21759b" name="Boxes_and_Design_Elements"></a>

<a id="Forums_and_Mailing_Lists" style="color: #21759b" name="Forums_and_Mailing_Lists"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Forums and Mailing Lists</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000">If you want to learn more about CSS, especially cutting edge CSS and web page designs, visit one of these forums and mailing lists to share your thoughts and learn from others.</p>

<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.css-discuss.org/" href="http://www.css-discuss.org/">CSS-Discuss</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://webdesign-l.com/" href="http://webdesign-l.com/">WebDesign-1 Discussions</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.sitepoint.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=1" href="http://www.sitepoint.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=1">SitePoint Forums on Web Page Design and CSS</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Books" style="color: #21759b" name="Books"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Books</span></h2>
<p style="color: #000000">The following are some of the best books to help you learn more about CSS and web page design.</p>

<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://zeldman.com/dwws/" href="http://zeldman.com/dwws/">Designing with Web Standards The bible, by Jeffrey Zeldman</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://www.simplebits.com/publications/solutions/" href="http://www.simplebits.com/publications/solutions/">Web Standards Solutions</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" style="color: #4ca6cf" title="http://meyerweb.com/eric/writing.html" href="http://meyerweb.com/eric/writing.html">All books by Eric Meyer</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>CSS Coding Standards</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/css-coding-standards/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 10:42:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=132</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2 class="handbook-page-title" style="color: #555555">CSS Coding Standards</h2>
<ul id="postlist" style="color: #555555">
	<li id="prologue-4082" class="post-4082 handbook type-handbook status-publish hentry selected">
<div id="content-4082" class="postcontent">

Like any coding standard, the purpose of the WordPress CSS Coding Standards is to create a baseline for collaboration and review within various aspects of the WordPress open source project and community, from core code to themes to plugins. Files within a project should appear as though created by a single entity. Above all else, create code that is readable, meaningful, consistent, and beautiful.

Within core stylesheets, inconsistencies will often be found. We are working on addressing these and make every effort to have patches and commits from this point forward follow the CSS coding standards. More information on the above and contributing to UI/front-end development will be forthcoming in a separate set of guidelines.
<h2 id="structure" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Structure <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#structure">#</a></h2>
There are plenty of different methods for structuring a stylesheet. With the CSS in core, it is important to retain a high degree of legibility. This enables subsequent contributors to have a clear understanding of the flow of the document.
<ul>
	<li>Use tabs, not spaces, to indent each property.</li>
	<li>Add two blank lines between sections and one blank line between blocks in a section.</li>
	<li>Each selector should be on its own line, ending in either a comma or an opening curly brace. Property-value pairs should be on their own line, with one tab of indentation and an ending semicolon. The closing brace should be flush left, using the same level of indentation as the opening selector.</li>
</ul>
Correct:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_850065" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-1</code><code class="css plain">,</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css plain">#selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-2</code><code class="css plain">,</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css plain">#selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-3</code> <code class="css plain">{</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">color</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#000</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
Incorrect:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_143580" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-1</code><code class="css plain">, #selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-2</code><code class="css plain">, #selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-3</code> <code class="css plain">{</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">color</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#000</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css plain">#selector</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-1</code> <code class="css plain">{ </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">; </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">color</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#000</code><code class="css plain">; }</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="selectors" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Selectors <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#selectors">#</a></h2>
With specificity, comes great responsibility. Broad selectors allow us to be efficient, yet can have adverse consequences if not tested. Location-specific selectors can save us time, but will quickly lead to a cluttered stylesheet. Exercise your best judgement to create selectors that find the right balance between contributing to the overall style and layout of the DOM.
<ul>
	<li>Similar to the <a style="color: #267db2" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Coding_Standards">WordPress Coding Standards</a> for file names, use lowercase and separate words with hyphens when naming selectors. Avoid camelcase and underscores.</li>
	<li>Use human readable selectors that describe what element(s) they style.</li>
	<li>Attribute selectors should use double quotes around values</li>
	<li>Refrain from using over-qualified selectors, <code style="color: #000000">div.container</code> can simply be stated as <code style="color: #000000">.container</code></li>
</ul>
Correct:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_690657" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#comment-form {</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1em</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css plain">input[type=</code><code class="css string" style="color: blue !important">"text"</code><code class="css plain">] {</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">line-height</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1.1</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
Incorrect:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_165252" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1">8</div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2">9</div>
<div class="line number10 index9 alt1">10</div>
<div class="line number11 index10 alt2">11</div>
<div class="line number12 index11 alt1">12</div>
<div class="line number13 index12 alt2">13</div>
<div class="line number14 index13 alt1">14</div>
<div class="line number15 index14 alt2">15</div>
<div class="line number16 index15 alt1">16</div>
<div class="line number17 index16 alt2">17</div>
<div class="line number18 index17 alt1">18</div>
<div class="line number19 index18 alt2">19</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#commentForm { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Avoid camelcase. */</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css plain">#comment_form { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Avoid underscores. */</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2"><code class="css plain">div#comment_form { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Avoid over-qualification. */</code></div>
<div class="line number10 index9 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number11 index10 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number12 index11 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number13 index12 alt2"><code class="css plain">#c</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1</code><code class="css plain">-xr { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* What is a c1-xr?! Use a better name. */</code></div>
<div class="line number14 index13 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number15 index14 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number16 index15 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number17 index16 alt2"><code class="css plain">input[type=text] { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Should be [type="text"] */</code></div>
<div class="line number18 index17 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">line-height</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">110%</code> <code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Also doubly incorrect */</code></div>
<div class="line number19 index18 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="properties" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Properties <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#properties">#</a></h2>
Similar to selectors, properties that are too specific will hinder the flexibility of the design. Less is more. Make sure you are not repeating styling or introducing fixed dimensions (when a fluid solution is more acceptable).
<ul>
	<li>Properties should be followed by a colon and a space.</li>
	<li>All properties and values should be lowercase, except for font names and vendor-specific properties.</li>
	<li>Use hex code for colors, or rgba() if opacity is needed. Avoid RGB format and uppercase, and shorten values when possible: #fff instead of #FFFFFF.</li>
	<li>Use shorthand (except when overriding styles) for background, border, font, list-style, margin, and padding values as much as possible. (For a shorthand reference, see <a style="color: #267db2" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/CSS_Shorthand">CSS Shorthand</a>.)</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="property-ordering" class="toc-heading" style="font-weight: bold;color: #555555">Property Ordering <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#property-ordering">#</a></h3>
<blockquote style="color: #888888">
<p style="color: #555555">“Group like properties together, especially if you have a lot of them.”
— Nacin</p>
</blockquote>
Above all else, choose something that is meaningful to you and semantic in some way. Random ordering is chaos, not poetry. In WordPress Core, our choice is logical or grouped ordering, wherein properties are grouped by meaning and ordered specifically within those groups. The properties within groups are also strategically ordered to create transitions between sections, such as background directly before color. The baseline for ordering is:
<ul>
	<li>Display</li>
	<li>Positioning</li>
	<li>Box model</li>
	<li>Colors and Typography</li>
	<li>Other</li>
</ul>
Things that are not yet used in core itself, such as CSS3 animations, may not have a prescribed place above but likely would fit into one of the above in a logical manner. Just as CSS is evolving, so our standards will evolve with it.

Top/Right/Bottom/Left (TRBL/trouble) should be the order for any relevant properties (e.g. margin), much as the order goes in values. Corner specifiers (e.g. border-radius-*-*) should be top-left, top-right, bottom-right, bottom-left. This is derived from how shorthand values would be ordered.

Example:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_576069" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#overlay {</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">position</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">absolute</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">z-index</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">padding</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">10px</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">color</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#777</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
Another method that is often used, including by the Automattic/WordPress.com Themes Team, is to order properties alphabetically, with or without certain exceptions.

Example:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_482978" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">#overlay {</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">color</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#777</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">padding</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">10px</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">position</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">absolute</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">z-index</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h3 id="vendor-prefixes" class="toc-heading" style="font-weight: bold;color: #555555">Vendor Prefixes <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#vendor-prefixes">#</a></h3>
Updated on 2/13/2014, after <a style="color: #267db2" href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/changeset/27174">[27174]</a>:

We use <a style="color: #267db2" href="https://github.com/nDmitry/grunt-autoprefixer">grunt-autoprefixer</a> as a pre-commit tool to easily manage necessary browser prefixes, thus making the majority of this section moot. For those interested in following that output without using Grunt, vendor prefixes should go longest (-webkit-) to shortest (unprefixed). All other spacing remains as per the rest of standards.
<div>
<div id="highlighter_493200" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">.sample-output {</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css plain">-webkit-box-shadow: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">inset</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#eee</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css plain">-moz-box-shadow: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">inset</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#eee</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css plain">box-shadow: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">inset</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#eee</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="values" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Values <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#values">#</a></h2>
There are numerous ways to input values for properties. Follow the guidelines below to help us retain a high degree of consistency.
<ul>
	<li>Space before the value, after the colon</li>
	<li>Do not pad parentheses with spaces</li>
	<li>Always end in a semicolon</li>
	<li>Use double quotes rather than single quotes, and only when needed, such as when a font name has a space.</li>
	<li>0 values should not have units unless necessary, such as with transition-duration.</li>
	<li>Line height should also be unit-less, unless necessary to be defined as a specific pixel value. This is more than just a style convention, but is worth mentioning here. More information:<a style="color: #267db2" href="http://meyerweb.com/eric/thoughts/2006/02/08/unitless-line-heights/">http://meyerweb.com/eric/thoughts/2006/02/08/unitless-line-heights/</a></li>
	<li>Use a leading zero for decimal values, including in rgba().</li>
	<li>Multiple comma-separated values for one property should be separated by either a space or a newline, including within rgba(). Newlines should be used for lengthier multi-part values such as those for shorthand properties like box-shadow and text-shadow. Each subsequent value after the first should then be on a new line, indented to the same level as the selector and then spaced over to left-align with the previous value.</li>
</ul>
Correct:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_279226" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1">8</div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2">9</div>
<div class="line number10 index9 alt1">10</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">.class { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Correct usage of quotes */</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background-image</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">url</code><code class="css plain">(images/bg.png);</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">font-family</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css string" style="color: blue !important">"Helvetica Neue"</code><code class="css plain">, </code><code class="css color1" style="color: gray !important">sans-serif</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css plain">.class { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Correct usage of zero values */</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">font-family</code><code class="css plain">: Georgia, </code><code class="css color1" style="color: gray !important">serif</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">text-shadow</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">-1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css plain">rgba(</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">, </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">, </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code><code class="css plain">, </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0.5</code><code class="css plain">),</code></div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2"><code class="css spaces">                       </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">1px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number10 index9 alt1"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
Incorrect:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_335198" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">.class { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Avoid missing space and semicolon */</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">background</code><code class="css plain">:</code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">#fff</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css plain">.class { </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Avoid adding a unit on a zero value */</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">margin</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">20px</code> <code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0px</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="media-queries" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Media Queries <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#media-queries">#</a></h2>
Media queries allow us to gracefully degrade the DOM for different screen sizes. If you are adding any, be sure to test above and below the break-point you are targeting.
<ul>
	<li>It is generally advisable to keep media queries grouped by media at the bottom of the stylesheet.
<ul>
	<li>An exception is made for the wp-admin.css file in core, as it is very large and each section essentially represents a stylesheet of its own. Media queries are therefore added at the bottom of sections as applicable.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Rule sets for media queries should be indented one level in.</li>
</ul>
Example:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_1428" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css plain">@media </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">all</code> <code class="css plain">and (</code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">max-width</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">699px</code><code class="css plain">) and (</code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">min-width</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">520px</code><code class="css plain">) {</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css spaces">        </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* Your selectors */</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="commenting" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Commenting <a class="anchor" style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#commenting">#</a></h2>
<ul>
	<li>Comment, and comment liberally. If there are concerns about file size, utilize minified files and the SCRIPT_DEBUG constant. Long comments should manually break the line length at 80 characters.</li>
	<li>A table of contents should be utilized for longer stylesheets, especially those that are highly sectioned. Using an index number (1.0, 1.1, 2.0, etc.) aids in searching and jumping to a location.</li>
	<li>Comments should be formatted much as PHPDoc is. The <a style="color: #267db2" href="http://cssdoc.net/">CSSDoc</a> standard is not necessarily widely accepted or used but some aspects of it may be adopted over time. Section/subsection headers should have newlines before and after. Inline comments should not have empty newlines separating the comment from the item to which it relates.</li>
</ul>
For sections and subsections:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_24089" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2">7</div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1">8</div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2">9</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/**</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">* #.# Section title</code></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">*</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">* Description of section, whether or not it has media queries, etc.</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">*/</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number7 index6 alt2"><code class="css plain">.selector {</code></div>
<div class="line number8 index7 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">float</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">left</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number9 index8 alt2"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
For inline:
<div>
<div id="highlighter_984436" class="syntaxhighlighter  css">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="gutter" style="color: #afafaf !important">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2">1</div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1">2</div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2">3</div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1">4</div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2">5</div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1">6</div></td>
<td class="code">
<div class="container">
<div class="line number1 index0 alt2"><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* This is a comment about this selector */</code></div>
<div class="line number2 index1 alt1"></div>
<div class="line number3 index2 alt2"><code class="css plain">.another-selector {</code></div>
<div class="line number4 index3 alt1"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">position</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">absolute</code><code class="css plain">;</code></div>
<div class="line number5 index4 alt2"><code class="css spaces">    </code><code class="css keyword" style="font-weight: bold !important;color: #006699 !important">top</code><code class="css plain">: </code><code class="css value" style="color: #009900 !important">0</code> <code class="css color3" style="color: red !important">!important</code><code class="css plain">; </code><code class="css comments" style="color: #008200 !important">/* I should explain why this is so !important */</code></div>
<div class="line number6 index5 alt1"><code class="css plain">}</code></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
<p class="toc-jump"><a style="color: #267db2" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/coding-standards/css/#top">Top ↑</a></p>

<h2 id="best-practices" class="toc-heading" style="color: #555555">Best Practices</h2>
Stylesheets tend to get long in length. Focus slowly gets lost whilst intended goals start repeating and overlapping. Writing smart code from the outset helps us retain the overview whilst remaining flexible throughout change.
<ul>
	<li>If you are attempting to fix an issue, attempt to remove code before adding more.</li>
	<li>Magic Numbers are unlucky. These are numbers that are used as quick fixes on a one-off basis. Example: <code style="color: #000000">.box { margin-top: 37px }</code>.</li>
	<li>DOM will change over time, target the element you want to use as opposed to “finding it” through its parents. Example: Use <code style="color: #000000">.highlight</code> on the element as opposed to <code style="color: #000000">.highlight a</code> (where the selector is on the parent)</li>
	<li>Know when to use the height property. It should be used when you are including outside elements (such as images). Otherwise use line-height for more flexibility.</li>
	<li>Do not restate default property &amp; value combinations (for instance <code style="color: #000000">display: block;</code> on block-level elements).</li>
	<li></li>
</ul>
</div></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
