	<item>
				<title>Importing Content</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/importing-content/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 11:19:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=139</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress currently supports importing data in the form of posts (articles) and most of the details or features supported by the content publishing platform.

Many of the following Content Import scripts can be found under <b>Tools → <a class="mw-redirect" title="Tools Import SubPanel" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Tools_Import_SubPanel">Import</a></b> menu of your WordPress administration interface.

If you run into specific problems, a search on the <a class="external text" title="http://wordpress.org/support/" href="http://wordpress.org/support/">WordPress Support Forum</a> will likely lead to a solution, or try the Codex <a title="FAQ" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/FAQ">FAQ</a>. Users of a blogging system not listed here who wish to switch to WordPress are invited to ask for help in the <a class="external text" title="http://wordpress.org/support/" href="http://wordpress.org/support/">WordPress Support Forum</a> as well.

To help you understand the differences between WordPress and other existing software, we recommend you review the <a title="WordPress Features" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Features">WordPress Features</a> and more on <a title="Working with WordPress" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Working_with_WordPress">Working with WordPress</a>.

<a id="Before_Importing" name="Before_Importing"></a>
<h3><span class="mw-headline">Before Importing</span></h3>
If your exported file is very large, the import script may run into your host's configured memory limit for PHP.

A message like "Fatal error: Allowed memory size of 8388608 bytes exhausted" indicates that the script can't successfully import your XML file under the current PHP memory limit. If you have access to the <tt>php.ini</tt> file, you can manually increase the limit; if you do not (your WordPress installation is hosted on a shared server, for instance), you will have to break your exported XML file into several smaller pieces and run the import script one at a time.

If the import process is run again with the same data file after stopping midway through, it could result in duplicate data, missing data or other errors in the destination database.

For those with shared hosting, the best alternative may be to consult hosting support to determine the safest approach for running the import. A host may be willing to temporarily lift the memory limit and/or run the process directly from their end
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Importing from [X]HTML</span></h2>
Using trial and error one can make an e.g., perl script to concatenate [X]HTML files as RSS &lt;item&gt;s, saving into a single file.xml, then import that as RSS. Note however to first remove any newlines between &lt;p&gt;..&lt;/p&gt;s, as mentioned above.

The format allowed is quite simple in fact. Just make each HTML file into an &lt;item&gt; as below and concatenate them together:

[xml]
&lt;item&gt;
 &lt;pubDate&gt;Wed, 30 Jan 2009 12:00:00 +0000&lt;/pubDate&gt;
 &lt;category&gt;Kites&lt;/category&gt;
 &lt;category&gt;Taiwan&lt;/category&gt;
 &lt;title&gt;Fun times&lt;/title&gt;
 &lt;content:encoded&gt;&lt;p&gt;What great times we had...&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And then Bob...&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/content:encoded&gt;
&lt;/item&gt;
&lt;item&gt;...
[/xml]

Just be sure the &lt;content:encoded&gt; line is a single long line with no newlines embedded.

If your HTML is well-formed, you can try using the <a class="external text" title="http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/import-html-pages/" href="http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/import-html-pages/">Import HTML plugin</a>.

<a id="Importing_from_a_Site_of_Static_Pages" name="Importing_from_a_Site_of_Static_Pages"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Importing from a Site of Static Pages</span></h2>
A <a class="external text" title="http://lists.automattic.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2011-February/037772.html" href="http://lists.automattic.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2011-February/037772.html">discussion in February 2011 on the wp-hackers email list involved importing 6,000 static pages into WordPress</a>. A number of responses recommended using the <a class="external text" title="http://sourceforge.net/projects/simplehtmldom/" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/simplehtmldom/">PHP Simple HTML DOM Parser</a> to facilitate the porting of the pages.

<a id="Google_Blog_Converters" name="Google_Blog_Converters"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Google Blog Converters</span></h2>
In case the above methods don't work, you can try <a class="external text" title="http://code.google.com/p/google-blog-converters-appengine/" href="http://code.google.com/p/google-blog-converters-appengine/">Google Blog Converters</a>.

This tool can convert Blogger export into WordPress format. It also supports conversion from Movable Type &amp; LiveJournal to Blogger format. You can take the Blogger format then convert it again into WordPress format.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>139</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-27 11:19:33</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:10:"HT_Vote_Up":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:10;s:2:"ip";s:14:"203.117.37.237";s:4:"time";i:1407311901;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:10:"HT_Vote_Up":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:10;s:2:"ip";s:14:"185.13.202.202";s:4:"time";i:1407414544;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:10:"HT_Vote_Up":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:10;s:2:"ip";s:12:"66.249.65.68";s:4:"time";i:1407427232;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:12:"HT_Vote_Down":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:0;s:2:"ip";s:12:"66.249.65.76";s:4:"time";i:1407427325;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:12:"HT_Vote_Down":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:0;s:2:"ip";s:13:"108.59.84.228";s:4:"time";i:1407768655;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:10:"HT_Vote_Up":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:10;s:2:"ip";s:14:"201.206.10.154";s:4:"time";i:1407895941;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:12:"HT_Vote_Down":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:0;s:2:"ip";s:13:"66.249.64.136";s:4:"time";i:1408030893;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_ht_voting</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[O:12:"HT_Vote_Down":4:{s:9:"magnitude";i:0;s:2:"ip";s:14:"223.255.245.37";s:4:"time";i:1408038584;s:7:"user_id";i:0;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Editing Files</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/editing-files/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 11:20:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[demo1]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=140</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There are times when you will need to edit the WordPress files, especially if you want to make changes in your <a title="Using Themes" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">WordPress Theme</a>. WordPress features a built-in editor for editing files from within your browser whilst online: <a title="" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_Files#Using_the_Theme_Editor_and_Plugin_Editor">The Theme Editor</a>. You can also edit files copied or stored on your computer, and then upload them to your site using an <a title="FTP Clients" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/FTP_Clients">FTP client</a>.

Before editing any of your WordPress files, check the following:

<dl><dt>BACKUP! And Work from Backups </dt><dd>Work from copies of backup files when possible and/or make sure that you <a title="WordPress Backups" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Backups">backup your information</a> frequently as you work and make changes. Keep backups in a safe place.</dd></dl><dl><dt><a title="Changing File Permissions" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Changing_File_Permissions">File Permissions</a> </dt><dd>When working online, you need to set the appropriate file permissions to modify and save them. If you see a note at the bottom of the WordPress Built-in Editor panel that says <b>"If this file was writable you could edit it."</b>, this means that you need to change the file permissions before you can make any changes.</dd></dl><dl><dt>Use a <a title="Glossary" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Glossary#Text_editor">Text Editor</a> to Edit Files </dt><dd>To make changes to files outside of the built-in Plugin or Theme Editor, use a text editor. <b>DO NOT USE A WORD PROCESSING PROGRAM.</b> Word processors change the quote marks to characters and may convert other characters, or bring in unwanted code; these changes will cause the file to break. There are also some HTML generator programs that should not be used, for similar reasons.</dd></dl><a id="Using_the_Theme_Editor_and_Plugin_Editor" name="Using_the_Theme_Editor_and_Plugin_Editor"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Using the Theme Editor and Plugin Editor</span></h2>
WordPress contains two built-in editors that allow you to edit Theme files directly from within your browser. They are called the<b>Theme Editor</b> and <b>Plugin Editor</b>.

Access the Theme Editor from the <a class="mw-redirect" title="Administration Panels" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration</a> &gt; <a class="mw-redirect" title="Administration Panels" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Appearance">Appearance</a> &gt; <a class="mw-redirect" title="Appearance Editor SubPanel" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Appearance_Editor_SubPanel">Editor</a> menu.

The Plugin Editor is located at <a class="mw-redirect" title="Administration Panels" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels">Administration</a> &gt; <a class="mw-redirect" title="Administration Panels" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Panels#Plugins">Plugins</a> &gt; <a class="mw-redirect" title="Plugins Editor SubPanel" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Plugins_Editor_SubPanel">Editor</a>.

To view a file in these editors, click on the file from the right-hand side list.

More information on editing themes is available at <a title="Theme Development" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development">Theme Development</a> and <a title="Using Themes" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Themes">Using Themes</a>. You can learn more about editing plugins at <a title="Writing a Plugin" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Writing_a_Plugin">Writing a Plugin</a> and <a title="Plugin Resources" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Plugin_Resources">Plugin Resources</a>.

Be aware that if the theme you edit is updated, your changes will be overwritten. To better organize your changes and protect them from updates, consider creating a <a title="Child Themes" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Child_Themes">Child Theme</a> in which to keep all your changes.

<a id="What_Files_Can_Be_Edited.3F" name="What_Files_Can_Be_Edited.3F"></a>
<h3><span class="mw-headline">What Files Can Be Edited?</span></h3>
From within the WordPress Built-in Editor, the following file types may be edited, if <a title="Changing File Permissions" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Changing_File_Permissions">writable</a>:
<ul>
	<li><a title="Glossary" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Glossary#HTML">HTML</a></li>
	<li><a title="Glossary" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Glossary#PHP">PHP</a></li>
	<li><a title="Glossary" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Glossary#CSS">CSS</a></li>
	<li>.htaccess</li>
	<li>TXT (and related text-like files such as RTF)</li>
</ul>
<a id="Things_You_Need_to_Know" name="Things_You_Need_to_Know"></a>
<h3></h3>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Using JavaScript</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/using-javascript/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 11:23:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[demo1]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=141</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[JavaScript will work within WordPress. It can be used within <a title="Templates" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Templates">WordPress template files</a> in WordPress Themes or <a title="Child Themes" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Child_Themes">Child Themes</a>. JavaScript cannot be added to post content without a special WordPress Plugin that removes the filters that prevent unwanted code within the post content area, for the protection of the user.

<a id="JavaScript_in_Template_Files" name="JavaScript_in_Template_Files"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">JavaScript in Template Files</span></h2>
The safe and recommended method of adding JavaScript to a WordPress generated page, and WordPress Theme or Plugin, is by using <a title="Function Reference/wp enqueue script" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/wp_enqueue_script">wp_enqueue_script()</a>. This function includes the script if it hasn't already been included, and safely handles dependencies.

To use JavaScript repeatedly within your site, you can either set the call for the JavaScript, or the script itself, in the <tt>head</tt> of your <tt>header.php</tt> template file, between the meta tags and the style sheet link, no differently than you would if you were using JavaScript in any HTML page. To "load" the JavaScript file into your site, in the <tt>head</tt>, add something like this:

[php]
&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; src=&quot;/scripts/emailpage.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
[/php]

If your custom JavaScript isn't working after including the previous line of code in your <tt>header.php</tt> template file, use the following line of code.

[php]
&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; src=&quot;&lt;?php bloginfo('template_url'); ?&gt;/pathto/yourscript.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
[/php]

Include the leading forward slash "/", even if your file is located in the root of your theme.

Be sure that you define the <tt>type</tt> correctly, as your site will not validate without it.

In the spot where you wish to use the JavaScript, set the call for the JavaScript. For example, you are using a JavaScript that sets a link for users to "email this page" to a friend, and you want it to be under the post title. It might look like this:

[php]
&lt;h3 class=&quot;storytitle&quot;&gt;
 &lt;a href=&quot;&lt;?php the_permalink() ?&gt;&quot; rel=&quot;bookmark&quot;&gt;
 &lt;?php the_title(); ?&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;emailpage&quot;&gt;
 &lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;!--//--&gt;&lt;![CDATA[//&gt;&lt;!--
 emailpage();
 //--&gt;&lt;!]]&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
[/php]

<a id="JavaScript_in_Posts" name="JavaScript_in_Posts"></a>
<h2>Using Multiple JavaScript Files Inside One Post or Page</h2>
When using functions laying in multiple JavaScript files, add all the JavaScript references in the <tt>header.php</tt>. If you really need to write the script reference in the <tt>body</tt> of the post or Page, ensure that the URL to the JavaScript file starts with the forward-slash ("/"), which is your webserver's <i>document root</i> (the "htdocs" directory in the case of Apache webserver). This is called a <i>fixed URL</i>. If you do not specify the starting slash ("/"), it becomes a <i>relative URL</i> ("../../relative/path/to/javacripts/file.js"), and <i>is calculated relative to the current location</i> in the directory structure.

If you do this, you will almost surely <i>need to maintain several versions of this reference</i> because different parts of the displayed content are generated from different locations. For example, <b>pages are created from</b> .php template files in the <b>WordPress root directory</b> (note that this is <i>not</i> the webserver's document root), <b>while posts are created</b> from .php template files <b>in the chosen theme's directory</b> ("/path-to-wordpress-root/wp-content/themes/yourtheme/partofpost.php"). These are two different paths.

<a id="Troubleshooting_Javascript" name="Troubleshooting_Javascript"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Troubleshooting Javascript</span></h2>
If you are having trouble with including JavaScript inside a post, use the <a class="external text" title="http://dev.wp-plugins.org/wiki/TextControl" href="http://dev.wp-plugins.org/wiki/TextControl">Text Control Plugin</a>, which allows you to control, on a global or per post basis, the ability to turn off WordPress' automatic formatting features, which can quickly turn code into something readable instead of executable. Set the options on the post that you will be using the JavaScript on to have <b>No Formatting</b> or<b>Markup</b> or <b>nl2br</b>, and <b>No Character Formatting</b>. You may have to experiment to get it to work. As a reminder, when using the Text Control Plugin, you must first <i>Save and Continue Editing</i> the post in order to see the Text Control Plugin options.

If you choose <b>No Formatting</b>, your post's text will run together, so you will have to add paragraph tags and other HTML tags in order to format your page, as WordPress normally does that for you.

If your JavaScript does not work, triple check that you have not made any errors during the cut and paste into a group or single file. Be sure you used a text editor, and not a word processing program, to create the JavaScript file. Check the name of the function in the script file, as well as on your site. Not all JavaScript may work, and could possibly conflict with your PHP commands, but this is very rare.

If you are having trouble with this, the <a class="external text" title="http://wordpress.org/support" href="http://wordpress.org/support">WordPress Support Forum</a> may be able to help.

<a id="Resources" name="Resources"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Resources</span></h2>
<ul>
	<li><a class="external text" title="http://digwp.com/2009/06/including-jquery-in-wordpress-the-right-way/" href="http://digwp.com/2009/06/including-jquery-in-wordpress-the-right-way/">DigWP - Including jQuery in WordPress the Right Way</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" title="http://digwp.com/2009/06/use-google-hosted-javascript-libraries-still-the-right-way/" href="http://digwp.com/2009/06/use-google-hosted-javascript-libraries-still-the-right-way/">DigWP - Use Google Hosted JavaScript Libraries - Still the Right Way</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" title="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript">Mozilla Developer JavaScript Resource</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" title="http://php.resourceindex.com/" href="http://php.resourceindex.com/">PHP Resource Index</a></li>
	<li><a class="external text" title="http://www.php-scripts.com/" href="http://www.php-scripts.com/">PHP Scripts</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Adding AJAX</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/knowledgebase/adding-ajax/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 11:29:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[demo3]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?post_type=ht_kb&#038;p=142</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><span class="mw-headline">What is Ajax?</span></h2>
<p>Ajax (Asynchronous JavaScript And XML) is a technology that allows a web page to perform actions or update dynamically, without completely reloading. The idea is that by using Ajax technology, a website can be more responsive and interactive than a non-Ajax site. For instance, without Ajax, Google Maps might require you to click a link on the left side of the map and wait for the page to reload in order to scroll the map to the left. With Ajax, you can instead simply drag the map to scroll, and while there might be a small delay, it is a much shorter delay and less disruptive process than if you had to wait for the entire page to load.</p>
<p>If you already know about Ajax, and want to use it in a plugin you are developing, skip to <a title="AJAX in Plugins" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/AJAX_in_Plugins">AJAX in Plugins</a>.</p>
<a id="How_does_Ajax_work.3F" name="How_does_Ajax_work.3F"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">How does Ajax work?</span></h2>
<p>Ajax technology is actually fairly simple to describe. Basically, the web programmer connects a link, button, or some other type of user interface element on the web page to a JavaScript program. When the user activates the interface (clicks on the link, drags the mouse, etc.), the JavaScript program sends some information or a request for data to a URL on the web server. Next, a program on the web server (probably also created by the web programmer) processes the request and sends back a response or some data. Typically the data is in XML format, but that is not actually required. When the data or response arrives in the browser, the JavaScript program receives an "asynchronous" notification, so that it can be processed or displayed appropriately.</p>
<p>Today, Ajax is supported in some form by most visual web browsers (though only if the user has JavaScript turned on). Of course, like most complex JavaScript, there are differences between how browsers implement JavaScript. However, these are not too difficult to overcome. The only real restriction on Ajax is that the URL you send the information to has to be on the same website as the URL the JavaScript came from. Other than that, the uses for the technology are only limited to what you can figure out how to program.</p>
<a id="Ajax_in_WordPress" name="Ajax_in_WordPress"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Ajax in WordPress</span></h2>
<p>Because of its responsiveness, Ajax technology is being adopted by all sorts of websites -- and WordPress is no exception. Currently, the core of WordPress uses Ajax only in the administration screens. For instance, Ajax is used for instant updates when you are doing comment moderation, and when you are adding and deleting items from lists such as categories, blogroll, and posts; Ajax is also the technology behind the auto-save functionality on post and page editing screens. Several themes and plugins also use Ajax; for instance, some post rating plugins use Ajax to store the visitor's rating in the database and then display an updated average rating.</p>
<a id="Further_Reading" name="Further_Reading"></a>
<h2><span class="mw-headline">Further Reading</span></h2>
<a id="General_Information" name="General_Information"></a>
<h3><span class="mw-headline">General Information</span></h3>
<ul>
    <li><a class="external text" title="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AJAX" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AJAX">Wikipedia Ajax article</a></li>
    <li><a class="external text" title="http://www.adaptivepath.com/publications/essays/archives/000385.php" href="http://www.adaptivepath.com/publications/essays/archives/000385.php">Adaptive Path's Ajax essay</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Developer_Information" name="Developer_Information"></a>
<h3><span class="mw-headline">Developer Information</span></h3>
<ul>
    <li><a title="AJAX in Plugins" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/AJAX_in_Plugins">Codex - Ajax in Plugins</a> - WordPress-specific information on how to add Ajax to plugins</li>
    <li><a class="mw-redirect" title="Function Reference/WP Ajax Response" href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/WP_Ajax_Response">WP_Ajax_Response Class Reference</a> - Responding to Ajax requests</li>
    <li><a class="external text" title="http://www.fiftyfoureleven.com/resources/programming/xmlhttprequest/examples" href="http://www.fiftyfoureleven.com/resources/programming/xmlhttprequest/examples">Working Examples of Ajax</a></li>
    <li>Simplified Ajax - <a class="external text" title="http://www.modernmethod.com/sajax/" href="http://www.modernmethod.com/sajax/">SAJAX</a></li>
</ul>
<a id="Generally_Speaking" name="Generally_Speaking"></a>
<h3><span class="mw-headline">Generally Speaking</span></h3>
<ul>
    <li>"<a class="external text" title="http://hinchcliffe.org/archive/2007/01/20/12675.aspx" href="http://hinchcliffe.org/archive/2007/01/20/12675.aspx">Eleven Emerging Ideas for SOA Architects in 2007</a>" from Hinchcliffe.org; "This allows widgets, Ajax applications, and mashups to be wired together so quickly it can almost be done in real-time with the latest tools."</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_target</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_classes</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{i:0;s:0:"";}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_xfn</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_url</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How to Build a Brand that Wins Over Customers’ Hearts and Wallets</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/how-to-build-a-brand-that-wins-over-customers-hearts-and-wallets/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Jul 2014 17:04:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=18</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

Contributions from users like you keep the project vibrant, alive and on the path of progress.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
				<title>Acquiring Customers with Email</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/acquiring-customers-with-email/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:47:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=36</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>10 Stories of Unforgettable Customer Service</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/10-stories-of-unforgettable-customer-service/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:47:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=37</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_target</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_classes</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{i:0;s:0:"";}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_xfn</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_url</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_menu_item_orphaned</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1406216849]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Hello world!</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/hello-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Jul 2014 14:00:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=1</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Welcome to <a href="http://demo.herothemes.com/">Hero Themes Demos</a>. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start blogging!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>25 Ways to Thank Your Customers</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/25-ways-to-thank-your-customers/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:47:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=38</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>38</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-23 13:47:43</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 13:47:43</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>25-ways-to-thank-your-customers</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="customer"><![CDATA[customer]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="list"><![CDATA[list]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="retention"><![CDATA[Retention]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="reward"><![CDATA[reward]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[8483]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_dp_original</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[37]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[83]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

				<title>A Brief Guide to a Better Email</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/a-brief-guide-to-a-better-email/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:47:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=40</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.

Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The Art of Customer Loyalty</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/the-art-of-customer-loyalty/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:51:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=46</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.

		<wp:post_id>46</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-23 13:51:54</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 13:51:54</wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
				<title>10 Ways to Convert Customers with Psychology</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/10-ways-to-convert-customers-with-psychology/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:51:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=47</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time.]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>47</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-23 13:51:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 13:51:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>10-ways-to-convert-customers-with-psychology</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="acquisition"><![CDATA[Acquisition]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="business"><![CDATA[business]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="conversion"><![CDATA[conversion]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="customers"><![CDATA[customers]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="psychology"><![CDATA[psychology]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key>_dp_original</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[46]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[8483]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

	<item>
				<title>The Business Case for Loving Customers</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/the-business-case-for-loving-customers/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:52:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=50</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

	<item>
				<title>A Brief Guide to a Better Email</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/a-brief-guide-to-a-better-email-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 13:52:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Admin User]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=51</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 13:52:11</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>a-brief-guide-to-a-better-email-2</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
				<title>Theme Feedback</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/forums/topic/theme-feedback/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Jul 2014 18:40:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/forums/topic/theme-feedback/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We will shortly be adding a theme feedback mechanism to Hero Themes products. The features you want in your Hero Theme.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>155</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-27 18:40:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-27 18:40:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>theme-feedback</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>104</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>topic</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="topic-tag" nicename="hero-themes"><![CDATA[hero themes]]></category>
		<category domain="topic-tag" nicename="products"><![CDATA[products]]></category>
		<category domain="topic-tag" nicename="support-3"><![CDATA[support]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_bbp_akismet_result</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_bbp_akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1406486401.27144908905029296875;s:7:"message";s:37:"Akismet cleared this post as not spam";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:7:"richard";}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>A Fantastic New Theme That Will Delight Your Customers</title>
		<link>http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/news/a-fantastic-new-theme-that-will-delight-your-customers/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Jul 2014 11:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[richard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.herothemes.com/helpguru/?p=170</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WordPress started in 2003 with a single bit of code to enhance the typography of everyday writing and with fewer users than you can count on your fingers and toes. Since then it has grown to be the largest self-hosted blogging tool in the world, used on millions of sites and seen by tens of millions of people every day.

The following is a list of some of the features that come standard with WordPress, however there are literally tens of thousands of plugins that extend what WordPress does, so the actual functionality is nearly limitless. You are also free to do whatever you like with the WordPress code, extend it or modify in any way or use it for commercial projects without any licensing fees. That is the beauty of <a href="#">free software</a>, free meaning not only price but also the freedom to have complete control over it.
<h2>Your Entire Workflow</h2>
WordPress can take the place of your entire workflow from the initial draft to the time you hit publish – spelling, grammar, collaboration, and review – there’s no need for e-mails back-and-forth or expensive desktop software.
<blockquote>WordPress is a powerful semantic publishing platform, and it comes with a great set of features designed to make your experience as a publisher on the Internet as easy, pleasant and appealing as possible.</blockquote>
We are proud to offer you a <i>freely distributed</i>, <i>standards-compliant</i>, <i>fast</i>, <i>light</i> and <b>free</b> content management system, with <i>sensible default settings and features</i>, and an <i>extremely customizable core</i>.
<h3>Beyond Black and White</h3>
Everything that makes webpages feel rich – pictures, videos, music, documents – can feel right at home in WordPress. With a drag-and-drop file uploader that uses the latest technology to ensure your file effortlessly makes it to the web page every time, and a media browser to help you store, organize and find the files you’re looking for, WordPress hosts the files that make your pages pop:
<ol>
	<li>Your Site is Your Castle</li>
	<li>Extensive APIs</li>
	<li>Enterprise Ready</li>
	<li>Interoperability</li>
	<li>Trust, but Verify</li>
</ol>
Not everyone is evil, but keep those who are in check by limiting which html tags are kosher on your weblog.
<h3>The Right Tuxedo for Any Content</h3>
Your content deserves the best. The site should conform to your content, not the other way around. WordPress comes with a full theme system which makes designing everything from the simplest site to the most complicated portal a piece of cake. Have a new design every day. Your ideas should look as good as what they say.

Everything you see here, from the documentation to the code itself, was created by and for the community. WordPress is an Open Source project, which means there are hundreds of people all over the world working on it. (More than most commercial platforms.) It also means you are free to use it for anything from your cat’s home page to a Fortune 500 web site without paying anyone a license fee and a number of other important freedoms.
<h3>Obsessively Organized</h3>
It doesn’t matter how much content you have, if your visitors can’t find it. WordPress organizes your content by day, by month, by year, by author, by category — any way you can describe it — and dynamically creates browsable archives so things always stay up to date.

WordPress has killer search baked in. Every word you write is fully searchable through a single box at the top of each page and if your users choose to use an external search engine like Google, rest assured, WordPress will present your content in a way that all but ensures it makes it to the top of the results every time

<strong>With built in support for custom post types and custom taxonomies, if you can dream it, WordPress can make it a reality.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>170</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-28 11:00:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-28 11:00:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>a-fantastic-new-theme-that-will-delight-your-customers</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="announcements"><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[8483]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_status</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_time</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1406727183]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
